div.head: Title of Chapter
div.p:
1st to 3rd verse. XII. We must fix our attention
to day, in the first place, upon the various dis
pensations, which have been, both before, and af
ter the flood, held forth to man, as the means
of his salvation. The first of these dispensa
tions, was that before the fall, which was en
tire perfection in the creature, and power to
obtain his own salavation, in consequence
of which, a proportionate demand was made
upon him, of perfect obedience, by his Creator.
But this perfection was lost, and the
power of obtaining salvation by that dispen
sation, was at an end. Then there came a
change, but it is to be observed, that it
was only a change of the creature, not of
the Creator, God made the same demands
upon man, but another mode was ordain
ed to him, of fulfilling them; The Creator
was, and is, the same, under every
change and every dispensation and these
various changes were only different modes
of showing his glory, his justice, and his
soverignty, Now, we must bear in mind
that the dispensation after was quite uni
versal in its character, the promise of sal
vation was equally extended to all the hu
man race, it shut out none, and there
was no benefit given to one individual,
which was not attainable by all, it was
universal in efficacy, although it was not
so in facts, and it would also have been
on account of sin.

But this universality is now lost, in the
administration to Abraham. A particular
nation is selected descending from a single
individual; But we should observe, that al
though, this particular administration, is
limited, the former one is still continued
and still extending its benefits to all men,
it is an addition, not limitation, it is
introduced into the former economy, with
out destroying it. And we have several
proofs of this. For under what dispensa
tion can we suppose what Melchisedek was
a high preist, Certainly under the first, and
not under the Abrahamic We may now
enter into the particulars of the calling of
Abraham. 31st verse, 11. It may be as
ked, how Abraham, as it is here told us
departed, with his family, from Ur of Chaldees,
apparently before he was called by
God. But, I think it is evident that God
had appeared to him before he left Hur and
arrived in Haran. For, there is no doubt
that the beginning of the twelfth chapter
goes back to events which had happened
previously to his departure from Ur.
Let us look at the seventh chapter of Acts,
and the 2nd verse. Stephen says, "The God
of Glory appeared unto our father Abraham
when he was in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt
in Charran, which is Haran , according
to the Greek pronunciation" and said un
to him Get thee out of thy country,
and from thy kindered and come into the land
which I shall show thee For taking the
order of the words in Genesis, we should i
magine, that Abraham was called after
he had dwelt in Haran, or Charran, but we
may be sure, that Stephen and Moses were
in perfect unison, and that, as Moses says
"the Lord had said to Abram," the seeming
contradiction is only from the transposi
tion of the words

We may next consider the situation of
Abraham and his family his religious views
, and condition, before he was called, in or
der to preserve the worship of the True God,
who was, at this period, almost entirely
forgotten, amid the depravity and idolatry
so generally prevailing, prevailing so com
pletely indeed, that we have authority
for supposing that there were idols, even
even in Abrahams own family; Now, if
this state of things had continued for a very
small time longer, the earth would have been
left without one single testimony of even the
existence of the true God. It was therefor nec
essary, immediately to bring Abraham away
from his house, and from his kindered, and to
wean him from the worship of the Idols, which
were placed even in his own house. For, we
read in the twenty fourth chapter of Joshua, and
the second verse, "Your fathers dwelt on the other
side of the flood in old time, (that is, on the other
side of the river Euphrates; which was called the
flood, because it was the largest river then
known; and not meaning the deluge) even Terah,
the father of Abraham and the father of
Nahor, and they served other Gods," it is distinct
ly stated that they were Idolaters, and al
though it does not positively affirm, that
Abraham himself was a worshipper of idols
, yet, I think we may suppose him to have
been so, before he was called of God, and his
future blessings announced to him.

In these blessings, there are a few particulars
which may be severally noticed. There is,
first, a simple promise made to Abraham
that the Lord will shew him a land, there
is nothing more, there is no imitation
given as to its character, its name, or its po
sition, it is not said whether it shall be
barren, or fruitful, large, or small, desert
or inhabited. He is left to exercise his
faith, he must leave his house, his coun
try, his kindred, and he must trust all
his interests in the hands of his Creator.
This however, he does, and what without a
moments hesitation, as the Lord had spo
ken unto him, and his instant and willing
compliance presents us with an example
of what our conduct ought invariably
to be, with regard to the promises of
God. But how much, how con
stantly we deviate from the rule of con
duct which the patriarch has, in this
instance, so strictly observed. How daily,
how hourly, are we wishing, and even
stipulating to the Almighty to under
stand the entire bearing of everything
which is written in Scripture,
When we ought, without a moments hes
itation, to trust ourselves, and our con
cerns wholly to the keeping, and man
agement, of a true, kind, and a faith
ful Creator, we are as suspicious
as if we were moving in the country
of an artful, and vigilant enemy, and
where an ambush was laid for us in every
thicket. How different how exceedingly
different, was the spirit of Abraham. He
knew only, but he knew that certainly
that God had spoken, and that the
path which he had to follow, was in
stant and unhesitating confidence, &
he therefore waits for nothing more. If
we were to follow his example, and, ha
ving seen some of the promises clearly
and completely fulfilled, will believe
that those which are yet obscure to us,
shall, in time, be discovered to be e
qually true we shall then be able to
travel on fearlessly, with such a
degree of firmness as will enable us,
trusting in the faith of our Creator, to
relieve our minds from all worldly f
ears and troubles. Let us remember, that
very few promises indeed had been made
to Abraham, in comparison of the num
ber which have been delivered to us, and,
that, of those few, none had been hither
to fulfilled, that he saw those prophe
cies only under an obscure and dawn
ing light, which are seen by us under
a full blaze of noontide splendour, and let
us then who rise so far above in the
degree of explicitness belonging to those
prophecies which we are required and co
mmanded to trust to, not fall far be
low him in either the greatness, or
the readiness of our faith.

The next article of this promise, is, that
the Lord will make of Abraham a great
nation, showing, what we have men
tioned before, that the Abrahamic dis
pensation was limited to a peculiar
nation, the descendants of Abraham, al
though it shut out no one from
the previous administrations.
There is the same want of perspicuity in
this promise Abraham is not told when
or where, or how, or under what circum
stances the Lord will make him a great
nation, and Abrahams faith is again put
to the test, but it fails not The verse
goes on I will bless thee. Now, we should
remark here, that to be made a great
nation alone might, or might not be a
blessing, most probably might on the
contrary prove a curse, for wealth, power,
glory, any, or all of the good things of this
world, only can prove blessings, when they
are accomplished by the blessing of the Almighty,
and it is therefore, this blessing,
which constitutes what is really good
or desireable, in every thing. We might
suppose kingdoms and rulers and nations
to be submitted to Abraham, or forces,
and wealth and power, and dominion, to
be given unto him, but if we suppose
him alone possessed of infinitely
more than all these, and beyond the
power of man to injure him, while on the
other hand, though he might be endowed
with every good thing which earth
could bestow upon him, if we suppose
him void of divine grace, we suppose
him unblest, with every blessing, and un
happy with every happiness, while the pow
er in which lay his pride, or the domin
ion in which lay his power, might, in
the end, only prove preludes to his fear
ful and irrrevocable overthrow. It is
only when the blessing of God rests
upon a man, that we can imagine
him happy, or upon a nation, that
we can imagine it great.

Again, it is promised to him, that his
name shall be made great. Now, we
are not to infer from this, that Abraham
desired a great name. On the contra
ry had he desired it, it would most probably
not have been granted him, because, we
may be sure, that this was not to min
ister to his pride, but to support his
weakness. It was to encourage him in his
humble simplicity, and in order that he might
not yield to any despondency, which, other
wise, might have overcome him, when he
found himself in a strange land, where the
God whom he served was not known, and far
from his own his own country, his kin
dred, his friends, and his family. The pro
mise to make his name great, was to
encourage his diffidence, and not to sup
port his ambition.

The next promise, is, that he shall be
a blessing. This is a very great, and im
portant addition, to the former promise,
that he should be blessed. For, had this
only been granted him, his enjoyment
would have been personal only, he would
have stood alone, and his happiness would
have been greatly cloyed, by seeing the
misery, the vice, the violence, and the dep
ravity with which he was surrounded.
We cannot suppose one, who has attained
a tall rock, in the middle of a tempes
tuous ocean, and who sees his fellow‐be
ings perishing around him to be hap
py, although we may suppose him thank
ful, and we cannot suppose, that Abraham
would have been supremely happy,
although blest with all the good that
earth or heaven could give, had that
blessing been only personal: But, was it
not a great encouragement to him, when
he knew, that wherever he went, his pre
sence should scatter blessings on every
one around, that mirth should fol
low his footsteps, and gladness accom
pany his presence. This would se
cure the blessings of all around him, en
vy would not detract him, and malice
would not injure him, his benevolence
would be gratified, and his selfishness
forgotten, or subdued. Now, it may
be asked, if this circumstance, that Abraham
should be a blessing to all, was
not inconsistent with, or contradic
tory to, the limitation, the peculiar
limitation, of the Abrahamic dipsen
sation. We would answer No. For
although, on account of the peculiar cir
cumstances in which the patriarch was
placed, he might be forced so far, to en
ter into correspondence with the idolaters
by whom he was surrounded, and although
this correspondence might, in some de
gree bring a blessing upon them, although
he might, enter into traffic with them
and buy and sell, (as we see from the 9th
and following verses of the XXIII Chapter
that he bought a cave, from Ephron, of
the children, of Heth, for four hundreds
shekels of silver) yet we cannot suppos
that he was intimate with them. God
had pointed out to him the path which
he was to follow, and that was one of
entire seclusion and seperation, from
the rest of mankind, and it was his
bounden duty, under all circumstances
to stand aloof from all the worshippers
of other Gods, and to adhere to this se
vere rule so strictly, as even to with
draw himself from his own family, &
friends, when these went after unknown
gods, in short, all, that the smallest de
gree would interpose between him, and
the God whose servant he had been
appointed, must be entirely set aside.
And, let me say, that this should
be our line of conduct at the present
day, we should stand aloof from every
thing that, would seperate us, and our
heavenly Father. We must not enter
more into correspondence with world
ly men more than is absolutely neces
sary, we must set the world and the
things of the world aside, or we shall
share in their ruin. Lot did not ad
here strictly to this rul, but entered in
to an alliance with the people of Sodom
and Gomorrah, and although he himself
by a timely flight was enabled to es
cape, yet we know, that one individ
ual of his family, who left the city
of the idolaters with delay, and regret,
was overtaken by the same destruction
Let this, my friends be a warning to
us, and let us remember, that the less
we have to do with the things of this
world, the better we are preparing for anoth
er.

Again, the verse goes on, to say that God
not only will bless the friends of Abraham
but will set himself against his enemies
Still, we observe that is exactly the line of
enemies of his people may perhaps triumph
on the earth, but their triumph will be
but of short duration, and God will, in
the latter end, bring them to a fearful
account, for in all these things, we are
more than conquerors. Even on the ear
th, when he hath flourished for a little
time like a flower of the field, and spread
out his branches, like a green olive tree,
by the rivers of waters, yet but a little
while, and he passeth away, and the
place thereof shall know it no more
We have an example of this, in the battle
of kings, in which we are told that
Abraham, with three hundred and eigh
teen men, defeated the forces of the five
combined kings.
We now come to the last, but the prin
cipal part of this blessing, I say the prin
cipal, because in this part, the dispen
sation, which before was confined to
one peculiar nation, is here extended
to all the nations of the earth, "and in
thee shall all families of the earth, be
blessed. This part of the covenant, with
out doubt, refers to Christ, who, being
one ofthe descendants of Abraham, yet
extends the Abrahamic dispensation,
through his death, to the Jew, and the
Gentile, to the bond and the free, to all,
who will believe on him. Such were
the various circumstances of the Abra
hamic dispensation. And now, my
friends let me repeat, for I cannot
too often impress it upon you, how very
striking an instance, of the blessed pow
er of faith, we have in the conduct
of Abraham, on this occasion, Abraham
believed, and was steady in that
believe, under a very obscure vision on
ly of the glory of the Son of man
The gospel is delivered to us, under cir
cumstances exceedingly different, we have
line upon line, and precept upon precept.
The redeemer has appeared, and the bless
ing has been accomplished, and yet
we still find thousands disbelieving
this grand salvation Let me tell you
that the rejection of the Gospel, or its
neglect is a fearful and perilous crime. Let
us not be found guilty of either. Let
us receive it as Abraham did, and
cast off every thing that can come be
tween us and God, and may we be
found, in the latter days among those
families, who shall actually enjoy these
most precious, and imperishable blessings.
